awd_titl_txt: Gordon Research Conference and Seminar: Research at High Pressure
awd_abstract_narration:
The Research at High Pressure Gordon Conference (HP-GRC) is one of the oldest topical conferences held since the emergence of the field of high pressure and has been held uninterrupted for over 60 years. The HP-GRC is a multidisciplinary conference in the field of high pressure research, and this year?s HPGRC program consists of presentations on breakthrough and unpublished results obtained using high-pressure methods and new innovations for studying matter under extreme conditions. This conference brings together experts from the dynamic and static pressure communities across the world to present and discuss their new and unpublished results. Accompanied by an associated High Pressure Gordon Research Seminar (HP-GRS) this conference attracts many young researchers as well as pioneers of the
field. The collegial atmosphere of this conference accommodates many fruitful discussions, motivates new directions in the field of high pressure and promotes mentoring.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Since the Research at High Pressure GRC was founded in 1955 it has focused on high-pressure states of matter obtained under two main sub-fields: static and shock compression. Bridging the gaps in experimental time scales and the thermodynamic states separating these subfields has long been a major goal. This year we extended the theme of bridging gaps from time scale and temperature, to pressure range of interest, and future high-pressure science. New developments are narrowing the gaps from all sides and helping to unify our field.

Most of the high-pressure matter in the universe—planetary interiors—resides at intermediate temperatures between the cold-curve and the Hugoniot. We explored recent results bridging traditional isothermal and Hugoniot studies. Across our disciplines "high pressure" can legitimately describe pressures from 10 MPa to 10 TPa. We focused on pressures of importance to biology and chemistry, associating studies where compression is used to effectively explore and control material response. Relevant time scales for high-pressure studies range from picoseconds to eons. We looked at the evolution of phase transitions and of planets to sample some of this span. Much as hydrogen is the most common material in the universe, it has historically been the most common session in the High-Pressure GRC. This year we explored a new format where a hydrogen talk closes the last session each day, allowing interested participants to carry the discussion beyond the lecture hall. Finally, this meeting bridged to the future by considering innovative approaches and facilities that are building high expectations for Research at High Pressure yet to come:

  • Low / High Temperature: Accessing Relevant Thermal Energies
  • Low / High Pressure: Tuning Atomic Interactions to Meet Specific Needs
  • Picoseconds / Eons: Characteristic Timescales in the Universe
  • Present / Future: Innovative Approaches

The Gordon Research Seminar on Research at High Pressure was held prior to the Gordon Research Conference on High Pressure and focused on bridging the gap in highly compressed matter science. This Gordon Research Seminar on High Pressure gave graduate students and early career scientists a solid introduction to static and shock compression, which are the two main sub-fields of high-pressure technology. A keynote address focusing on the historical overview of the techniques was given by two senior scientists, along with the main driving science behind each sub-field.
